summary: This document is a chain of emails from June-July 2020 between FBI personnel and others regarding a 'Continued Presence' (CP) application for a victim in the Jeffrey Epstein case. The emails discuss logistics, required paperwork, and the legal criteria for granting CP status to victims of severe forms of human trafficking.

persons.name: Timothy S. Hruz
persons.role: FBI personnel overseeing Continued Presence Program
persons.context: Identified as the FBI contact overseeing the Continued Presence (CP) program, to whom inquiries about the Epstein victim's application should be directed.

persons.name: L. Tiddle
persons.context: FBI employee who provides contact information for Timothy Hruz regarding the Continued Presence program for an Epstein case victim.

persons.name: Paul Byrne
persons.context: NYPD officer copied on an email discussing the Continued Presence application process for an Epstein victim.

connections.description: Tiddle refers an inquiry about a Continued Presence application to Hruz, indicating Hruz oversees the program.

events.title: Meeting with Epstein victim for CP paperwork
events.description: An FBI case agent and victim specialist met with a victim in the Jeffrey Epstein case to complete Continued Presence application paperwork.

keyFacts: In mid-2020, FBI personnel were actively pursuing a 'Continued Presence' (CP) application for a victim in the Jeffrey Epstein case.
Continued Presence is a program granted only if a victim meets the definition of a severe form of human trafficking (forced labor or commercial sex acts).
The turnaround time for ICE to approve a CP application could be as high as six weeks as of June 2020.
The email chain involves coordination between FBI personnel in New York and potentially the NYPD regarding victim support procedures.
The document indicates ongoing post-investigation support for victims associated with the Epstein case.
